metadata.sermon_start_end: I DON’T like the way that God runs this world, do you? If I were running it instead of God, there would be no such thing as child abuse. There would be no crack and no homeless people. There would be no mental illness, no alcoholism, no pollution [...] Some day the Lord will indeed rise up to annul our covenant with death. He will rise up, and we will see that “death is swallowed up in victory” (1 Cor. 15:54). But for now, we his people have work to do. “Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand”

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus exclusively on the designated pericope. It wanders through Isaiah 55, Exodus 20, Exodus 3, Jeremiah 18, and Romans 9 before settling on the text. It treats 'the Bible' as a general source of ideas rather than recreating the specific text into a current word.
quotes: Maybe the basic message of the Bible is simply this...
Isaiah, speaking the word of the Lord, said that the people of Israel have made 'a covenant with death' (28:15).
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Eliminate the general 'Bible-overview' introduction. Focus immediately on why the 'Covenant with Death' in Isaiah 28 is unique compared to other warnings in the prophets.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher identifies the historical context of Israel's national security crisis and the 'strange work' of God. However, the exegesis is thin; it relies on Luther's later theological categories (proper/alien work) rather than a rigorous linguistic or historical analysis of the Hebrew text itself.
quotes: Isaiah was writing in a time when the nation of Israel was about to be overtaken by disaster because of her sins...
This was the passage that led Martin Luther to speak of God’s proper work and his alien work...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Provide deeper exposition of the 'precious cornerstone' mentioned in the text (v. 16) which the sermon largely ignores, and explain the specific historical 'covenant' Israel made with Egypt/death.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is exceptionally concrete, focusing on the murder of Yusef Hawkins and racial tensions in New York. It avoids 'general truths' by naming specific neighborhoods and events, aligning with Dekker's demand for the zeitgeist.
quotes: Friday’s paper contained a description of the death of Yusef Hawkins...
Merely to blame Bensonhurst or Howard Beach or rednecks is to 'take refuge in a falsehood'...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the text's specific logic (the 'overflowing scourge') rather than using the text as a hook for social commentary.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: There is a decent mixing of the Isaiah text with the Bensonhurst tragedy. The hearer is drawn into the text's 'covenant with death' through the lens of modern racial animosity. However, the first half of the sermon is a detached lecture on the nature of God.
quotes: The white kids certainly made a covenant with death that night as they waited in the street...
Isaiah, speaking the word of the Lord, said that the people of Israel have made 'a covenant with death' (28:15).
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Remove the long dogmatic preamble about 'God being God' and start the sermon where the text and the contemporary event intersect.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The 'misery' (sin/death) is strongly present. 'Redemption' is present but somewhat externalized as a future hope or a social 'repentance'. The psychological aspect of 'misery' (the fear in the victim's eyes) is well-handled.
quotes: He was frightened. He had terror in his eyes.
This submission to God’s judgment is accomplished through repentance.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Clarify the 'gratitude' aspect; the sermon ends on a call to 'work', which risks moralism if not rooted in the Spirit-awakened gratitude Dekker describes.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon takes the 'two ways' seriously, specifically the 'temporal loss' of a society perishing due to its choices. It avoids the 'liberal' pitfall of making everything safe by emphasizing the 'scourge' and 'alien work' of judgment.
quotes: If we keep on doing that, we will experience the full force of his left hand, his alien work.
A person can be lost in time... 'if we continue like this, society will perish'.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Connect the 'temporal loss' of society more clearly to the 'eternal loss' of the individual soul to satisfy both traditions Dekker mentions.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the telos, but it feels somewhat tacked on at the end. The sermon struggles to reconcile the 'alien work' of Isaiah with the person of Christ, resorting to a brief mention of the atonement without deep integration into the text's imagery.
quotes: He paid — he truly and fully paid — for the death of Yusef Hawkins...
The Son of God achieved the salvation of the world through suffering and death.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Show how Christ is the 'precious cornerstone' (v. 16) of the Isaiah passage itself, rather than bringing Him in as a separate theological necessity.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1950 words, the sermon likely clocks in just under the 20-minute threshold. While it has breadth, the first 800 words are spent on generalities rather than the 'depth' of the specific text.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Reallocate the time spent on the 'I am God and you are not' introduction to a deeper exploration of the Isaiah 28 imagery (the bed too short, the blanket too narrow).

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's ideal primarily due to a lack of focus on the specific Bible passage. It spends too much time on general dogmatic truths about God's sovereignty before engaging the text. However, it excels in concrete application and taking the 'two ways' (judgment/loss) seriously within a contemporary context.
strengths: Concrete application: The use of the Yusef Hawkins case provides the 'true truth' Dekker demands.
Thematic seriousness: It does not shy away from God's 'alien work' or the reality of judgment.
weaknesses: Lack of specificity: The sermon treats the Bible as a collection of general ideas rather than focusing on what Isaiah 28 says that is found 'nowhere else'.
Structural separation: The first half is dogmatic lecture; the second half is sermon. They are not sufficiently interwoven.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a borderline sermon. It possesses the 'seriousness' and 'concreteness' Dekker requires, but fails the formal requirement of being an 'exposition of THIS specific passage'. It functions more as a topical speech on God's judgment using Isaiah as a secondary witness.
